posts.post_content: @darkfury [Evacuation](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Evacuation) Everything in magic has an answer.You're also assuming you have enough time to get off a 4 card combo against an aggro deck or that your opponent doesn't counter any of the 4 spells you need to get that combo off. And even then all the player would have to do is [Disenchant](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Disenchant) the greaves and [Journey to Nowhere](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Journey to Nowhere) [Path to Exile](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Path to Exile) [Swords to Plowshares](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Swords to Plowshares) the Cho-Manno, or the player could use [Oblivion Ring](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Oblivion Ring) on the greaves, bounce the O-Ring to their hand at the end of your turn with a [Boomerang](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Boomerang) and toss it back down on the Cho-Manno. 2-card combos beating your 4 card combos is not what you want in a combo deck.
posts.html:
@darkfury Evacuation Everything in magic has an answer.You're also assuming you have enough time to get off a 4 card combo against an aggro deck or that your opponent doesn't counter any of the 4 spells you need to get that combo off. And even then all the player would have to do is Disenchant the greaves and Journey to Nowhere Path to Exile Swords to Plowshares the Cho-Manno, or the player could use Oblivion Ring on the greaves, bounce the O-Ring to their hand at the end of your turn with a Boomerang and toss it back down on the Cho-Manno. 2-card combos beating your 4 card combos is not what you want in a combo deck.

posts.post_content: Question: I have been playing magic for a few years, but I still can't figure this one out. Say your opponent is attacking with a 4/4 with trample, you block with cho-manno. Does the attacking creature deal you any damage? Trample means if a creature deals enough damage to kill a creature, then the rest is dealt to you, but cho manno is never dealt any damage. What happens?
posts.html:
Question: I have been playing magic for a few years, but I still can't figure this one out. Say your opponent is attacking with a 4/4 with trample, you block with cho-manno. Does the attacking creature deal you any damage? Trample means if a creature deals enough damage to kill a creature, then the rest is dealt to you, but cho manno is never dealt any damage. What happens?
Report Abuse  
Posted By: LukeMan (1/20/2010 8:28:53 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: @LukeMan: You're right, Cho-Manno is never dealt any damage. But you are. Trample works by assigning damage equal to the defending creature's toughness to the creature, then the rest to the player. So in your example, two damage would be assigned to the Cho-Manno (which is, of course, prevented) and two would trample over to you.
posts.html:
@LukeMan: You're right, Cho-Manno is never dealt any damage. But you are. Trample works by assigning damage equal to the defending creature's toughness to the creature, then the rest to the player. So in your example, two damage would be assigned to the Cho-Manno (which is, of course, prevented) and two would trample over to you.
